Research Paper Highly efficient hydrogenation of furfural to 2-methylfuran over Cu-Ce/NAC catalysts: New insights into cerium promoter Ren Zhou Writing – original draft Data curation a b Yanhong Quan Investigation Formal analysis a b ⁎ Jun Ren Writing – review & editing Supervision a b ⁎ a State Key Laboratory of Clean and Efficient Coal Utilization, Taiyuan University of Technology, Taiyuan 030024, China State Key Laboratory of Clean and Efficient Coal Utilization Taiyuan University of Technology Taiyuan 030024 China aState Key Laboratory of Clean and Efficient Coal Utilization, Taiyuan University of Technology, Taiyuan 030024, China b College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Taiyuan University of Technology, Taiyuan 030024, China College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Taiyuan University of Technology Taiyuan 030024 China bCollege of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Taiyuan University of Technology, Taiyuan 030024, China ⁎ Corresponding authors at: No. 79 Yingze West Street, Taiyuan 030024, China. No. 79 Yingze West Street Taiyuan 030024 China A series of CuyCe/NAC-7 catalysts with different Cu/Ce molar ratio were prepared by the wet-impregnation process and used in the liquid hydrogenation of furfural (FF) to 2-methylfuran (2-MF). In all cases, the selectivity of 2-MF showed a tendency of first increase and then decline with the Cu/Ce molar ratio increasing from 10 to 30, while a complete conversion of FF was achieved regardless of the Cu/Ce ratio. The Cu20Ce/NAC-7 catalyst showed the maximum 2-MF yield of 98.3 % with reliable stability even after 5 cycles, superior than Cu/NAC-7 and the reported Cu-based catalysts, which was mainly attributed to the higher concentration of Cu+ species with enhanced stability induced by Ce3+/Ce4+ redox cycling (Cu2+ +Ce3+ ⇋ Cu+ +Ce4+). Notably, it was found that the 2-MF yield exhibited positively linear correlations with the surface concentration of Cu+, which acted as the active sites in the CuyCe/NAC-7 catalysts for the reaction. Therefore, the work provided a facile strategy to develop highly efficient and stable Cu-based catalysts through introducing a metal additive for the hydrogenation of FF to 2-MF. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Furfural 2-MF Cu catalysts Ce additive Surface Cu+ species Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The development and utilization of biomass resources have alleviated the trend of increasing tension in petroleum resources, curtailed environmental pollution stemming from petroleum resource exploitation, and provided robust support for the nation's strategic objectives of carbon peak and carbon neutrality. Furfural (FF), a product of xylan hydrolysis under acidic conditions, serves as a pivotal platform molecule in the initial advancement of biomass resources [1]. A series of downstream products can be derived through FF hydrogenation processes, encompassing furfuryl alcohol (FA) [2], 2-methylfuran (2-MF) [3], 2-methyltetrahydrofuran (2-MTHF) [4], γ-valerolactone (GVL) [5], tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (THFA) [6], 1-pentanol (1-PEN) [7], etc. As the production process from aliphatic compounds to FA is gradually maturing, the exploration of deep hydrogenation treatment technology for aliphatic compounds (FF) holds significant development significance. Among of those derivative from FF, 2-MF exhibits dual functionality as both a chemical feedstock and clean biofuel, widely utilized in pesticides, pharmaceuticals, and fragrances. Furthermore, with high octane number and energy density, 2-MF can be also used as an ideal biomass-derived fuel [8]. The synthesis of 2-MF from furfural involves sequential hydrogenation of the aldehyde group on the furan ring. As early as 1947, Bremner [9] spearheaded research on hydrogenating FF to produce 2-MF using copper-based catalysts and obtained an 89.0 % yield of 2-MF at 250 °C. As the research progressed, numerous studies have been conducted on catalysts featuring noble metals such as Pd [10,11], Pt [12,13], and Ru [14,15] as active sites, however, these catalysts have not yielded remarkable outcomes in this reaction. Moreover, the high cost associated with noble metals hinders their widespread adoption in industrial applications. Compared to this, the development of non-noble metal catalysts holds greater practical significance. In recent years, there has been extensive interest in non-noble metal catalysts including Co [16], Ni [17,18], Cu [19–22] applied for FF hydrogenation. Compared with both Co-based [15] and Ni-based [17,18] catalysts, Cu-based catalysts exhibited superior catalytic performance. For instance, Maradur et al. [22] found that 11Cu(1.5 M)/ZIF-8 catalyst exhibited exceptional activity (FF conversion >99 % with 2-MF selectivity of 93.9 %) and good stability. Activated carbon (AC) possesses substantial specific surface area and well-developed internal pores, rendering it an exceptional catalyst support [23]. Concerning Cu-based catalysts, it is well known that achieving high dispersion of Cu species further enhances catalytic activity [24,25]. Moreover, reducing the loading of active metals on the catalyst represents an effective strategy for improving metal dispersion [26–28]. Compared to Al2O3 and other metal oxide supports, AC can be modified through heteroatom doping to enhance the interaction between metal and support [29–31]. Among these modifications, N element doping is an effective means of modifying carbon materials as it can promotes the formation and stability of metal species [32–34]. Previous studies have also confirmed that the introduction of nitrogen species in carbon materials enhances the dispersion of Cu species [35]. More importantly, carbon materials can undergo hydrothermal and other high-temperature treatment methods to enhance their surface defects. These defects can effectively inhibit the loss of Cu species through a pore limited effect [36], thereby improving the catalyst's anti-aggregation and anti-loss performance [36,37]. The exceptional catalytic activity of Cu-based catalysts in the FF hydrogenation process for 2-MF synthesis arises from the synergistic interaction between Cu0 and Cu+ sites as Huang et al. [38] proposed based on DFT calculations (in Scheme 1 ). Specifically, the Cu0 site facilitates H2 dissociation to generate active H, while the Cu+ site serves as an active center of adsorption and activation for FF as well as FA moleculars. Subsequently, the activated FA formes a carbocation at its side chain, which is followed by hydrogenation and dehydration to produce 2-MF through the carbocation on the side chain. In other words, the concentration of copper with different valence states significantly impacts the catalyst's performance. Undoubtedly, the incorporation of metal additives is a highly effective strategy for regulation of the distribution of copper species on the catalyst surface. In the reaction of FF hydrogenation, the introduction of promoters (Mo or Ni) has been confirmed to enhance the activity of copper-based catalysts. Specifically, An et al. [39] synthesized a Cu-Mo/CoOₓ catalyst using Mo as a promoter and found that the adsorption configuration of the C = O group in the FF molecule shifted from η¹-(O) to η²-(C,O) due to the introduction of Mo, which strengthened the adsorption capacity toward C = O on the catalyst surface and improved catalytic activity, achieving a 92 % yield of 2-MF. Wang et al. [40] prepared 2Ni-6Cu/CZ catalyst by introducing Ni as a promoter and used for FF hydrogenation to 2-MF. It was found that the incorporation of Ni could stabilized the adsorption of the C = O group in the FF molecule on the copper-based catalyst and induced further hydrogenation of the intermediate FA to produce 2-MF. However, the yield of 2-MF only reached 78.8 %. Mo and Ni acted as promoters could enhance catalytic activity by modifying the adsorption configuration of FF molecules, yet the yield of 2-MF still exhibits substantial room for improvement. Therefore, searching for new additives that can enhance and stabilize copper species is an important strategy for improving catalytic performance, based on the indispensable roles of Cu0 and Cu+ species [41]. In the study of CO preferential oxidation, Wang et al. [42] employed Ce as a promoter and found that the reversible conversion between Cu2+/Ce3+ ⇌ Cu+/Ce4+ dynamically modulated the valence states of copper in the catalyst, resulting in superior performance. Similarly, Liu et al. [43] demonstrated that Ce also played an exceptional role in regulating copper valence states during methanol steam reforming. Consequently, Ce as a promoter holds significant promise for tuning the valence-state distribution of Cu species, offering critical insights for advancing catalytic efficiency. In this paper, nitrogen-doped activated carbon (NAC-7) as a support to synthesize a series of catalysts with varying copper-cerium molar ratios (CuyCe/NAC-7) through wet impregnation method. These catalysts are employed for the liquid phase hydrogenation of FF to produce 2-MF. Furthermore, by integrating experimental findings and various characterization techniques, the influence of cerium additive on modulating the valence state of active copper metal and further enhancing catalytic activity was discussed. 2 Experiental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation 2.1.1 Preparation of NAC supports Weighing an appropriate amount of AC and ammonia water (concentration of 1 mol/L), mix them in a beaker according to a specific mass ratio, stir the mixture at room temperature for 2 h. The mixed solution is subsequently transferred into a hydrothermal kettle and subjected to a temperature of 180 °C for a duration of 12 h. Upon completion of the reaction, the resulting suspension was filtered and thoroughly washed, followed by filtration and washing until the support attains neutrality. Then, the support was transferred to an oven set at 80 °C for complete drying. The prepared support was denoted as NAC-x (x = 5, 7, 10, indicating the mass ratio of ammonia to AC). 2.1.2 Synthesis of CuyCe/NAC-7 catalysts The CuyCe/NAC-7 catalysts with varying copper-cerium molar ratios were synthesized using the wet impregnation method (y represents the copper-cerium molar ratio, y = 10, 20, 30, respectively). In this synthesis process, Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, Ce(NO3)2·6H2O and NAC-7 were combined in a beaker with deionized water. The mixture was then subjected to ultrasonication for 2 h at room temperature before being stirred to evaporate the solvent in a water bath at 85 °C. Subsequently, it was transferred to an oven and dried completely at 80 °C. Finally, the catalysts were reduced by treating them with a hydrogen and nitrogen mixture (nH2:nN2=100:80) at 400 °C for 2 h. Additionally, a same procedure was followed to prepare the 5 % Cu/NAC-7 catalyst. 2.2 Characterization techniques The specific surface area, pore diameter, and pore volume of the catalyst sample were measured using the BeiShiDe 3H-2000PS2 instrument to obtain the nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherm. Rigaku D/Max 2500 target diffractometer was employed to determine the copper species on the samples and record their X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) pattern. Agilent ICP-OES was utilized for determining the copper and cerium content of the samples. Elemental analysis (EA) was performed using the German Elementar Unicube instrument. To investigate the surface structure and morphology of the samples, a 200 KV field emission projection electron microscope (FEI Tecnai G2 F20) was employed for analysis, resulting in obtaining TEM images. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were conducted using a Thermo Escalab 250 xi analyzer. The H2-TPR and H2 N2O analyses were conducted using the PCA-1200 chemisorption instrument from Bei Jing Builder Electronic Technology, Inc. Subsequently, the sample's reduced temperature and copper dispersion were determined. For H2-TPR analysis, a 100 mg sample was heated to 100 °C under an argon atmosphere for 60 min to eliminate moisture. The sample was then reduced in a hydrogen-argon mixture (H2: Ar = 10:90) with a flow rate of 30 ml/min. The heating rate was increased to 500 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min while recording the hydrogen consumption as X during this process. After cooling the sample to room temperature, it was exposed to an N2O atmosphere with a flow rate of 30 ml/min, resulting in oxidation of surface copper into Cu2O. Finally, the oxidized sample was re-reduced using a hydrogen-argon mixture (H2: Ar = 10:90), and the hydrogen consumption during this process was recorded as Y. The dispersion (DCu) value was calculated based on Eq. (1): (1) D Cu = 2 Y X × 100 % . 2.3 Catalyst activity evaluation The reaction was conducted in a 50 mL stainless steel high-pressure reactor. A mixture of 1.0 g FF, 8.5 g ethanol (solvent), and 0.5 g dodecane (internal standard) along with the catalyst was added to the reactor. Hydrogen gas was then filled into the reactor and purged 5 times before pressurizing it to an appropriate level. The reactor was set and heated accordingly. After completion of the reaction, centrifugation and filtration were performed on the upper liquid phase in order to obtain clarified liquid product while simultaneously washing the catalyst with ethanol for subsequent cycle experiments according to the same procedure as before. Qualitative and quantitative analysis of products were carried out using GC-950 gas chromatograph by processing obtained data, which allowed calculation of FF conversion (CFF, %), selectivity towards main products and by-products (S2− MF, S2− MTHF, S1-PEN, SFA, SGVL, STHFA, %), as well as yield of 2-MF (Y2− MF, %). (2) C FF = n reacted FF n total FF × 100 % (3) S 2 − MF = n produced 2 − MF n reacted FF × 100 % (4) S 2 − MTHF = n produced 2 − MTHF n reacted FF × 100 % (5) S 1 − PEN = n produced 1 − PEN n reacted FF × 100 % (6) S FA = n produced FA n reacted FF × 100 % (7) S GVL = n produced GVL n reacted FF × 100 % (8) S THFA = n produced THFA n reacted FF × 100 % (9) Y 2 − MF = C FF × S 2 − MF × 100 % 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Catalytic test results 3.1.1 Catalytic activity 3.1.1.1 Effect of catalyst preparation condition Cu loading To determine the optimal Cu loading for the catalyst, AC was employed as the support, and catalysts with varying Cu loadings (1wt %, 3wt %, 5wt %, 10wt %, and 15wt %) were evaluated under identical reaction conditions. As shown in Table 1 , the FF conversion gradually decreased with increasing Cu loading, while the 2-MF selectivity exhibited an initial rose followed by a declined. The 5 %Cu/AC catalyst demonstrated the highest catalytic activity, achieving FF conversion of 96.6 % and 2-MF selectivity of 85.4 %. Therefore, the optimal Cu loading was fixed at 5 wt % and used in subsequent condition screening of catalysts. N doping amount During the hydrothermal process, AC was treated with varying concentration of ammonia solution. To screen the most suitable NAC carrier, the reaction was conducted under identical reaction conditions (6 h, 190 °C, 4 MPa). As shown in Table 2 , both FF conversion and 2-MF selectivity initially increased and then decreased as the increasing amount of ammonia solution used in the preparation process. Notably, Cu/NAC-7 exhibited optimal activity with 99.8 % FF conversion and 90.4 % for 2-MF selectivity). Therefore, NAC-7 was selected as the catalyst carrier. Cu/Ce molar ratio The activities of the three CuyCe/NAC-7 catalysts with Cu/Ce molar ratios (10, 20 and 30) were evaluated under optimal reaction conditions to identify the optimal Cu/Ce molar ratio. As shown in Table 3 , as the Cu/Ce molar ratio decreased, FF conversion remained at 100 %, while the selectivity of 2-MF increased from 93.3 % to 98.3 % and then decreased to 91.7 %. When the Cu/Ce molar ratio was either too high or too low, significant byproduct could be formed attributing to differences in the varying distribution of surface Cu species induced by electron transfer of Ce with variable valence state. Therefore, the optimal Cu/Ce molar ratio for the catalyst was determined to be 20. 3.1.1.2 Effect of reaction condition Reaction pressure Cu20Ce/NAC-7 catalyst was used for reaction pressure screening to evaluate its performance under different pressures (2 MPa, 3 MPa, 4 MPa) and identify the optimal reaction pressure. As shown in Fig. 1 (a), FF conversion remained stable at 100 % with increasing pressure, while the selectivity for 2-MF initially increased and then decreased, rising from 96.7 % to 98.3 % and then decreased to 97.2 %. At lower pressures, the concentration of FA in the products significantly increased, likely due to insufficient H2 in the reaction system. Conversely, at higher pressures, over-hydrogenation of the products occurred, leading to an elevated concentration of 2-MTHF. Therefore, the optimal reaction pressure for the Cu20Ce/NAC-7 catalyst was determined to be 3 MPa. Reaction temperature Cu20Ce/NAC-7 catalyst was evaluated for reaction temperature screening to assess its performance at different temperatures (170 °C, 180 °C, 190 °C) and identify the optimal reaction temperature. As shown in Fig. 1(b), complete FF conversion could be achieved regardless of reaction temperature, while the selectivity for 2-MF first increased from 93.4 % to 98.3 % and then decreased to 96.2 %. Trace amounts of 2-MTHF were observed in the products at both excessively low and high temperatures, likely due to incomplete hydrogenation and over-hydrogenation side reactions, respectively. Consequently, the optimal reaction temperature for Cu20Ce/NAC-7 was determined to be 180 °C. Reaction time Cu20Ce/NAC-7 was evaluated to identify its optimal reaction time in this process by testing varying durations (5 h, 5.5 h, 6 h). As shown in Fig. 1(c), FF conversion still remained constant at 100 % with increasing reaction time, while 2-MF selectivity increased from 92.5 % to 98.3 % and then decreased to 94.8 %. When the reaction time was 5 h, the selectivity for the intermediate product FA reached 7.5 %, indicating the reaction time was too insufficient to convert to the target product of FF. Conversely, trace amounts of 2-MTHF appeared in the products at 6 h, signifying over-hydrogenation occurred. Consequently, the optimal reaction time for FF selective hydrogenation to 2-MF over Cu20Ce/NAC-7 was determined to be 5.5 h. Additionally, under optimized conditions (180 °C, 3 MPa H2, 5.5 h), the catalytic activities of Cu20Ce/AC catalyst and Cu/NAC catalyst were comparatively evaluated to verify the respective contributions of N and Ce and the results of catalytic performance were shown in Table 4 . It was found that Cu20Ce/NAC-7 exhibited superior performance in both FF conversion and 2-MF selectivity compared to Cu20Ce/AC and Cu/NAC-7, which surpassed the level achieved by copper-based catalysts reported in the literatures (Table S1). More importantly, Cu20Ce/AC and Cu/NAC-7 showed close FF conversion (91.2 % and 92.4 %), while the former showed the lower 2-MF selectivity of 93.1 % than the latter of 96.0 %, indicating both N doping of the carrier and modification with Ce catalyst were very important. These results clearly demonstrated the enhancement of catalytic performance was derived from the combination of nitrogen doping and the introduction of Ce as a promoter. 3.1.2 Catalytic stability As depicted in Fig. 2 , the catalysts of Cu/NAC-7 and Cu20Ce/NAC-7 were subjected to 5 cycles under their respective optimized reaction conditions. The stability of these catalysts in the hydrogenation of FF to 2-MF was investigated by comparing the variations in their catalytic activity over the course of 5 cycles. After five consecutive cycles, the yield of 2-MF decreased from 90.2 % to 78.8 % for Cu/NAC-7, whereas Cu20Ce/NAC-7 exhibited enhanced stability with subtle decline from 98.3 % to 95.2 %, indicating the introduction of Ce effectively promoted catalytic stability of Cu20Ce/NAC-7 in FF hydrogenation to 2-MF. According to the literature [44], the inactivation behavior could be ascribed to copper species loss, the agglomeration of Cu particles [45], or the reduction of active Cu species. However, the true cause for the Cu/NAC-7 and Cu20Ce/NAC-7 would be identified through further research. In view of the variation in the stability of the catalysts, the ICP characterization was carried out, and the causes of catalyst inactivation were analyzed by combining TEM images. After five cycles, the Cu loading in Cu20Ce/NAC-7 decreased slightly from 5.11wt % to 4.94wt %, whereas Cu/NAC-7 exhibited a more significant reduction from 5.22wt % to 4.45wt %, indicating the introduction of Ce could hinder the surface Cu species from leaching. Moreover, TEM images (Fig. 5(e)-(f)) revealed varying degrees of Cu agglomeration in both catalysts, directly contributing to activity reduction. Obviously, the average copper particle size of Cu/NAC-7-spent reached 25.47 nm, whereas Cu20Ce/NAC-7-spent exhibited a smaller average crystallite size of 20.62 nm after five reaction cycles. The variation in crystallite size confirmed that Ce incorporation effectively mitigates Cu agglomeration during catalytic operation. Furthermore, XPS characterization (Fig. 7(d-f)) demonstrated that Cu+ concentration in Cu20Ce/NAC-7 declined marginally from 40.2 % to 39.1 %, while Cu/NAC-7 showed a more pronounced decrease from 32.5 % to 26.4 %, confirming the stabilizing effect of the Ce promoter on active Cu species. Therefore, the superior cycling stability of Cu20Ce/NAC-7 to Cu/NAC-7 could be attributing to the promotion of stability of both Cu particles and Cu+ concentration induced by the introduction of variable valence state Ce as a promoter. 3.2 Structural properties of Cu/NAC-7 and CuyCe/NAC-7 catalysts 3.2.1 N2 adsorption-desorption The pore size distribution curves and N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms for the catalysts Cu/NAC-7 and CuyCe/NAC-7, are presented in Fig. 3 . Table 5 displayed the relevant physical characteristics. Both supports and their corresponding catalysts exhibited type I isotherms in N2 adsorption-desorption measurements, with a concentrated pore size distribution between 3–4 nm, indicating that both samples were hierarchical pore materials [46]. Additionally, all samples displayed H4 hysteresis loops, suggesting the presence of predominantly "ink bottle" mesopores [47]. The adsorption-desorption and pore size distribution curves of Cu/AC and Cu/NAC-x catalysts were presented in Fig. S1, and the textural properties were listed in Table S2, Cu/AC catalyst and Cu/NAC-x catalysts exhibited pore sizes concentrated in the range of 3–5 nm. As shown in Table S2, after treatment with ammonia solution, AC exhibited an increasing tendency in specific surface area from 1200 m2/g (AC) to 1315 m2/g (NAC-7), indicating N doping was conducive to the enhancement of surface area, which may be one of the reasons for the excellent catalytic performance of Cu/NAC-7 and CuyCe/NAC-7 catalysts. 3.2.2 XRD The XRD patterns of Cu/NAC-x catalysts, CuyCe/NAC-7 catalysts, and their spent counterparts after cycling are presented in Fig. S2(e), Fig. 4 (a), and Fig. 4(b), respectively. The diffraction peak at 23.4° was attributed to the amorphous carbon, while the peak at 43.2 ° corresponds to the Cu(111) crystal plane [48]. Fig. 4(a) illustrated that an increase in Ce content led to a gradual decrease followed by an eventual increase in the intensity of the diffraction peak at 43.2° Notably, when the copper-cerium molar ratio reached 20, the copper diffraction peak exhibited its weakest intensity, indicating optimal copper dispersion on the surface of Cu20Ce/NAC-7 catalyst. After 5 cycles, there was a noticeable increase in intensity of the diffraction peaks at 43.2 ° for both catalysts to some extent. However, after 5 cycles, the diffraction peak intensity of copper (111) on the catalyst with Cu20Ce/NAC-7 was weaker than that on the catalyst with Cu/NAC-7. This observation suggested that the addition of Ce promoter enhances the anti-aggregation ability of the catalyst, resulting in reduced aggregation of copper species on the catalyst surface after reaction. The diffraction peaks of graphite carbon and copper on the NAC support, as depicted in Fig. S2(e), exhibit a reduced magnitude compared to those observed on the AC support. In Fig. S2(f), the peaks observed at 1360 cm⁻¹ and 1600 cm⁻¹ correspond to the D band (reflecting amorphous carbon structures in the material) and the G band (graphitic carbon), respectively. A higher intensity ratio (ID/IG) indicated a lower degree of graphitization [49,50]. Specifically, the ID/IG ratio was 1.28 for the AC support and 1.75 for the NAC support, indicating the generation of surface defects was caused from the introduced N species. In other words, NAC was more favorable for anchoring and dispersion of copper compared to AC [51]. 3.2.3 TEM The TEM images of catalysts Cu/NAC-7 and CuyCe/NAC-7 along with their corresponding particle size distribution histograms were presented in Fig. 5 . It was observed that the Cu particles exhibited a uniform distribution across the support surface in all catalysts. CuyCe/NAC-7 showed the smaller average copper particle size than Cu/NAC-7 (10.81 nm), indicating the introduced Ce could promote the reduction in Cu particle size. Specifically, when the Cu/Ce molar ratios in the catalysts were 30, 20, and 10, the corresponding average copper particle sizes were 9.26 nm, 8.82 nm, and 9.39 nm, respectively. In parallel, Fig. S2((a)-(d)) demonstrated that nitrogen doping altered the copper particle size on the catalyst surfaces. Compared with the particle size of Cu/AC (14.20 nm), Cu/NAC-x catalysts had obviously smaller particle size. For Cu/NAC-x catalysts, the copper particle size shows initially decreased and then increased with the x increased from 5 to 10 and the minimum of 10.81 nm is obtained in Cu/NAC-7. Therefore, both the nitrogen-doped modification of the support and the introduction of cerium as a promoter facilitated a reduction in copper particle size on the catalyst surface, which was consistent with XRD results. Furthermore, lattice fringes with spacings of 0.212 nm, 0.238 nm, 0.179 nm, and 0.266 nm were observed on the surface of CuyCe/NAC-7, corresponding to the Cu (111), Cu₂O (111), Cu (200), and CeO₂ (200), respectively. The H2 N2O titration was conducted on catalysts with different compositions, including Cu/NAC-x and CuyCe/NAC-7, to evaluate the dispersion of copper on the catalyst surface. The experimental results were presented in Table 5. The dispersion significantly increased with the increasing of nitrogen doping and reached up to the value of 14.8 % for the Cu/NAC-7 catalyst, significantly superior to that of Cu/AC (5.3 %). Furthermore, by introducing Ce into the NAC support system, the better copper dispersion could be achieved in CuyCe/NAC-7, specifically reaching values of about 19.9 %, 16.7 %, and 18.5 % for Cu20Ce/NAC-7, Cu10Ce/NAC-7, and Cu30Ce/NAC-7 respectively. 3.2.4 H2-TPR The H2-TPR curves of Cu/NAC-7 and CuyCe/NAC-7 catalysts were presented in Fig. 6 , exhibiting distinct broad peaks within the temperature range of 200–500 °C. These peaks arise from the conversion of Cu2+ to Cu+ and Cu0 species on the catalysts [52,53]. Notably, the reduction temperatures follow the order: Cu10Ce/NAC-7 (282 °C) > Cu20Ce/NAC-7 (276 °C) > Cu30Ce/NAC-7 (267 °C) > Cu/NAC-7 (238 °C), with the increased in Ce dosage in the catalyst, there was a gradual elevation of the corresponding reduction temperature, indicating an enhanced interaction between Cu and Ce with increasing Ce dosage. Furthermore, the higher reduction temperature observed for Cu/NAC-x catalyst in comparison to Cu/AC catalyst (Fig. S3(d)) suggested that nitrogen doping as a modification technique for AC could effectively enhance the interaction between the support and metal. In addition, nitrogen species can increase the dispersion of the copper species [35]. 3.2.5 XPS The Ce 3d XPS spectrum of the CuyCe/NAC-7 catalyst was presented in Fig. 7 (a). Cerium existed primarily in the forms of Ce3+ and Ce4+ in catalysts. In this spectrum,the peaks at approximately 885.4 eV (v1) and 903.9 eV (u1) were assigned to Ce3+ species, while the remaining 6 peaks (v0, v2, v3, u0, u2, u3) corresponded to Ce4+[54,55]. The contents of Ce3+ and Ce4+ species were determined based on their respective peak regions and were also summarized in Table 6 . As could be seen from Table 6, when the Cu/Ce molar ratio decreased from 30 to 10, the concentration of Ce³⁺ first increased from 29.9 % to 39.4 %, then decreased again to 30.5 %. Consequently, it was reasonably speculated that the interconversion of two valence states of cerium could be achieved through electron transfer, and these transferred electrons participate in the regulation of copper valence states, maintaining a relative balance between the concentrations of different valence states of copper ions and different valence states of cerium ions [45]. Due to the different dosage of cerium, when the concentration of Ce3+ and Ce4+ in catalysts with different copper-cerium molar ratios reaches equilibrium, the intensity of electron transfer is also different, which made the concentration of Cu+ in catalysts with different copper-cerium molar ratios change, thus affecting the catalytic activity. Fig. 7(b) displayed the Cu 2p3/2 XPS spectra of Cu/NAC-7 and CuyCe/NAC-7 catalysts. All catalysts exhibited significant signal peaks at approximately 932.5 eV and 934.5 eV that corresponded to (Cu0 and Cu+) and Cu2+ [56–58], respectively. Table 7 presented the concentrations and peaks of different copper species in each catalyst. Compared with the characteristic peaks observed in the spectrum of Cu/NAC-7, those of the CuyCe/NAC-7 catalysts all shifted to higher binding energy levels to varying degrees, indicating a pronounced interaction between copper and ancillary cerium. In addition, the process of interconversion between Ce3+ and Ce4+ was via the Cu2+/Ce3+ ⇌ Cu+/Ce4+ pathway, in which Ce3+ participated in regulating the valence state of copper by releasing electrons [44]. Consequently, as Cu/Ce molar ratio decreased, there was a continuous reduction in Cu2+ concentration accompanied by an increase in (Cu0 and Cu+) concentration. Notably, the Cu²⁺ concentration reached 14.3 % in Cu/NAC-7 and it declined to 13.2 % in Cu10Ce/NAC-7, further elucidating the important influence of cerium additives on the distribution of Cu with different valence state. Fig. 7(c) depicted the Cu LMM XPS spectra of Cu/NAC-7 and CuyCe/NAC-7 catalysts. The characteristic peaks corresponding to Cu0 and Cu+ in all catalysts were observed at approximately 916.5 eV and 912.5 eV, respectively [59,60]. The concentrations of active center Cu+ species were provided in Table 7. Compared with Cu⁺ concentration of Cu/NAC-7 (32.7 %), CuyCe/NAC-7 exhibites higher values and followed the sequence of Cu20Ce/NAC-7 (40.2 %) > Cu30Ce/NAC-7 (37.0 %) > Cu10Ce/NAC-7 (35.9 %), demonstrateding that appropriate amount of Ce additives could promote the formation of surface Cu⁺ species. By comparing the changes in different valence copper ion concentrations in catalysts Cu/NAC-7 and Cu20Ce/NAC-7, it was found that under the same reduction conditions, the introduction of Ce as a promoter inhibited excessive generation of Cu0. As a result, the concentration of active center Cu+ was increased. Furthermore, through a comparative analysis of the variations in copper ion concentrations at different valence states within the CuyCe/NAC-7 catalysts, it was observed that as the molar ratio of copper to cerium decreased, there was an initial increased followed by a subsequent decreased in Cu+ concentration, while conversely, the concentration of Cu0 exhibited an opposite trend. The increase in the amount of Ce additive in the catalyst led to enhanced electron release during the conversion process from Ce3+ to Ce4+, thereby facilitating the conversion of Cu2+ to Cu+. However, an excessive amount of Ce additive promotes the conversion of Cu+ to Cu0 [61]. This also elucidates why the catalyst's activity initially increased and then decreased as the molar ratio of copper to cerium decreases. Fig. 7(d and e) displayed the Cu 2p3/2 XPS spectra and Cu LMM XPS spectra for Cu/NAC-7-spent and Cu20Ce/NAC-7-spent catalysts, respectively. Table 6 listed the concentrations and peaks of different copper species in the catalysts. However, notable disparities in Cu+ concentration were observed between Cu/NAC-7-spent and Cu20Ce/NAC-7-spent catalysts subjected to identical cyclic processes. As evidenced in Fig. 7(f), after five cycles of catalytic reaction, the Cu+ concentration of Cu20Ce/NAC-7 catalyst decreased from 40.2 % to 39.1 %, whereas that of Cu/NAC-7 catalyst declined from 32.5 % to 26.4 %. By combining the variations in Ce3+ and Ce4+ concentrations within the Cu20Ce/NAC-7-spent catalyst, it was observed that Ce4+ could undergo conversion to Ce3+, thereby accepting electrons and actively participating in the modulation of copper valence states. This process effectively hindered the transformation of Cu+ to Cu0 [44], ensuring a stable concentration of Cu+ species within the catalyst and consequently enhancing its stability. The N 1S XPS results of Cu/NAC-x catalysts were listed in Table S3, while the Cu 2p XPS results of Cu/AC catalyst and Cu/NAC-x catalysts were summarized in Table S4. With increasing nitrogen doping, the combined content of pyridinic nitrogen and graphitic nitrogen, which were essential for copper species anchoring, initially rose from 31.6 % to 39.3 % and then decreased to 32.3 %. Correspondingly, the Cu⁺ concentration in Cu/NAC-x catalysts increased from 29.6 % to 32.5 % and then fell to 31.5 %, obviously exceeding 27.2 % of Cu⁺ concentration in the Cu/AC catalyst. This demonstrated that nitrogen doping enhanced surface Cu⁺ concentration, with an optimal doping level maximizing Cu⁺ content to achieve the highest catalytic performance. 3.3 Discussions Evaluation results of FF hydrogenation to 2-MF verified an important promotion of Ce additives, lying in that CuyCe/NAC-7 catalysts possessing the higher catalytic performance than Cu/NAC-7. CuyCe/NAC-7 catalysts showed FF conversion of 100 % regardless of Cu/Ce molar ratios. However, 2-MF yield exhibited a trend of initial increase and then decline with varying Cu/Ce molar ratios and the maximum with 2-MF yield of 98.3 % was obtained in Cu20Ce/NAC-7, surpassing the reported Cu-based catalysts in the literatures [20,21,40]. Notably, there was a closely positive relationship between surface Cu+ concentration and 2-MF yield in FF hydrogenation over all the investigated catalysts as shown Fig. 8 (a), indicative of the significant influence of Cu+ species on selective hydrogenation of FF to 2-MF. It is well-established that 2-MF is generated through sequential hydrogenation of FF, forming the intermediate FA [2] and by-products such as 1-pentanol during the reaction [7]. As experimentally verified by Zhang et al. [41], Cu0 primarily was responsible for the H2 dissociation to form active hydrogen species in FF hydrogenation, while Cu+ adsorbs FF in a vertical configuration [62]. Therefore, the regulation on surface Cu species with different valence state was very critical for the synthesis of 2-MF from FF hydrogenation. More importantly, the positively linear relationship between Cu dispersion and Cu+ concentration was obtained as shown in Fig. 8(b). This observation highlighted the significant impact of increasing Cu dispersion on enhancing Cu+ concentration. Combination between the shift toward a higher reduction temperature detected by H2-TPR and the shift to higher binding energy for Cu0 and Cu+ provided by XPS result once the Ce doping collectively confirmed the formation of Cu-Ce interaction, which would be favorable for Cu dispersion on the catalyst surface. Additionally, the concentration of surface Cu2+ species was reduced with the introduction of Ce. Meanwhile, the appropriate introduction of additive Ce helped to increase the concentration of Cu+ species and yet excessive Ce amount would result in the formation of more Cu0 species as provided by XPS results, which was most possibly derived from the fact that the mutual transformation between Ce3+ and Ce4+ actively participated in modulating the valence state of copper species by releasing electrons, thereby inhibiting the conversion from Cu+ to Cu0 and Cu2+. This was consistent with the results reported by Wang et al. [42] that Ce as a promoter modulated the valence state distribution of Cu species on catalyst surfaces, facilitating the formation of additional Cu+ sites. Furthermore, through comparing the recycling stability of Cu20Ce/NAC-7 with Cu/NAC-7, it was further revealed that cerium could effectively contribute to stabilizing Cu+ species during reaction, thereby enhancing catalyst durability. Critically, the introduction of optimal Ce loading promoted Cu+ formation as well as maintained its stability under reaction conditions. In summary, Cu20Ce/NAC-7 catalyst exhibited exceptional yield and cycle stability was derived from the NAC providing Cu anchoring sites as well as the inroduced Ce facilitating Cu-Ce interaction and maintaining large Cu+ concentration through mutual transformation between Ce3+ and Ce4+. 4 Conclusion A series of CuyCe/NAC-7 with different Cu/Ce molar ratio were prepared via the impregnation method using NAC as a supports and were used for FF hydrogenation to 2-MF. It was found that the selectivity of 2-MF showed a tendency of first increase and then decline with the Cu/Ce molar ratio increasing from 10 to 30, which was companied with complete conversion of FF regardless of the Cu/Ce molar ratio. Cu20Ce/NAC-7 had the excellent catalytic activity with 2-MF yield of 98.3 % and 5-cycle catalytic stability, superior to Cu/NAC-7 and the reported Cu based catalysts, benefiting from the enhanced and stable Cu+ concentration due to the introduction with Ce species appropriate amount. It was surprisingly found that there was a positively linear relationship between surface Cu+ concentration and 2-MF yield for all the fresh and spent catalysts, fully substantiating Cu+ species acted as an active sites for the reaction of FF hydrogenation to 2-MF. Innovatively, the equilibrium Cu2+ +Ce3+ ⇋ Cu+ +Ce4+ could be established under higher concentration of Ce3+ and the appropriate Cu-Ce interaction at Cu/Ce molar ratio of 20 verified by H2-TPR and XPS results, which facilitated the generation of more stable Cu+ species. The introduction of N species into the carrier and its carbon defects were conducive to the anchoring of copper species, while the additive cerium maintained the stability of Cu+ concentration, which significantly improved the stability of the Cu20Ce/NAC-7 catalyst. This study provided a novel approach for catalyst design for FF selective hydrogenation to 2-MF, focusing on optimizing the catalytic activity and stability by fine-tuning surface Cu species distribution via valence state variable Ce modification. coredata.dc:description: A series of CuyCe/NAC-7 catalysts with different Cu/Ce molar ratio were prepared by the wet-impregnation process and used in the liquid hydrogenation of furfural (FF) to 2-methylfuran (2-MF). In all cases, the selectivity of 2-MF showed a tendency of first increase and then decline with the Cu/Ce molar ratio increasing from 10 to 30, while a complete conversion of FF was achieved regardless of the Cu/Ce ratio. The Cu20Ce/NAC-7 catalyst showed the maximum 2-MF yield of 98.3 % with reliable stability even after 5 cycles, superior than Cu/NAC-7 and the reported Cu-based catalysts, which was mainly attributed to the higher concentration of Cu+ species with enhanced stability induced by Ce3+/Ce4+ redox cycling (Cu2+ +Ce3+ ⇋ Cu+ +Ce4+). Notably, it was found that the 2-MF yield exhibited positively linear correlations with the surface concentration of Cu+, which acted as the active sites in the CuyCe/NAC-7 catalysts for the reaction. Therefore, the work provided a facile strategy to develop highly efficient and stable Cu-based catalysts through introducing a metal additive for the hydrogenation of FF to 2-MF.
coredata.dc:title: Highly efficient hydrogenation of furfural to 2-methylfuran over Cu-Ce/NAC catalysts: New insights into cerium promoter
